arm_group.description: Patients previously treated with Debrase for burn debridement
Patients previously treated with local Standard of Care for burn debridement

brief_summary.textblock:
Once the victim survived the acute phase, the outcome of wound healing, the scarring, became
      a major medical issue with complications that may lead to cosmetic and functional sequelae.
      Scar tissue is clinically distinguished from normal skin by an aberrant color, rough surface
      texture, increased thickness (hypertrophy), contraction, firmness and sometimes, decrease
      function.

      Thus, functional and cosmetic outcomes became at least important as wound closure in
      assessing wound healing products

clinical_study.brief_title: Functionality Assessments in Patients (Adults and Children) Following Treatment With Debrase Compared to Standard of Care

detailed_description.textblock:
This is a multi-center, assessor-blinded study aiming to evaluate the long term
      functionality in adults and children who have participated in study MW2004-11-02 (previous
      phase 3 study).

      We had previously shown that by using the MVSS scale which includes objective assessment of
      the physical characteristics of size, shape, volume, color, texture, and pliability as well
      as structural, mechanical and physiologic characteristics, lower (favorable) scores in
      Debrase vs. SOC group were observed in sub-groups of highly functional body parts of the
      hands and feet. This study will include specific functionality evaluation using the "Lower
      Extremity Functional Scale" test for burns in the lower extremities and the "QuickDASH"
      outcome measure for burns in the upper extremities as well as range of motion measurements
      of the joints (knee, ankle, shoulder, elbow and wrist, as relevant).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Adults and children who had participated and completed study MW2004-11-02. Patients
             must be able to sign and dated written informed consent prior to study entry (by
             Patient or by a guardian, when applicable).

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  None

study_pop.textblock:
Adults and children who had participated and completed study MW2004-11-02 (previous phase
        3 study) will be contacted. Patients who will agree to participate in the study will be
        invited to the clinic for a one day visit for assessments.

keyword: Upper and lower Extremity for burned patients

facility.name: Clinic of Burns and reconstructive surgery hospital

clinical_study.official_title: Functionality Assessments in Patients (Adults and Children) Following Treatment With Debrase Compared to Standard of Care (SOC) Protocol MW2012-12-12

overall_official.affiliation: Department Head of Burs and Reconstructive Surgery

primary_outcome.description:
Functionality evaluation of wounds that have been treated by Debrase or SOC during the previous phase 3 study by:
Self-report questionnaires designed to measure physical function: the "Lower Extremity Functional Scale" test for burns in the lower extremities and the "QuickDASH" outcome measure for burns in the upper extremities.
Range of motion measurements of the following injured joints: knee, ankle, shoulder, elbow, wrist palm and fingers, as relevant.
primary_outcome.measure: Functionality evaluation using self reported questionnaires and ROM measurements

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
